etymologies: late 19th century: from German, from hinter ‘behind’ + Land ‘land’

definitions: the often uncharted areas beyond a coastal district or a river's banks

examples.text: early settlers were driven from the coastal areas into the hinterland

shortDefinitions: remote areas of country away from coast

definitions: an area surrounding a town or port and served by it

examples.text: the city had grown prosperous by exploiting its local western hinterland

shortDefinitions: area around or beyond major town or port

definitions: an area lying beyond what is visible or known

examples.text: in the hinterland of his mind these things rose, dark and ominous

shortDefinitions: area lying beyond what is visible or known
